children.value: You can Publish to EarthCODE in Many Different Ways!

children.label: You can Publish to EarthCODE in Many Different Ways!

children.value: EarthCODE provides a vibrant ecosystem of tools to publish your work automatically - these tools aim to fit the EO communities’ preferred ways of working (code, cli or UI), and data formats and storage options (zarr, local netcdf files, etc..).
In this workshop we will explore publishing to the EarthCODE catalog via
which automates the key steps outlined below.
The code for publishing via deep-code is available at this notebook:

is a lightweight python tool that comprises a command line interface(CLI)
and Python API providing utilities that aid integration of DeepESDL datasets,
experiments with EarthCODE.
You will need to first clone the deep-code repo and install it manually following the guide at

provides a command-line tool called deep-code, which has several subcommands
providing different utility functions.
Use the --help option with these subcommands to get more details on usage.

The CLI retrieves the Git username and personal access token from a hidden file named
.gitaccess. Ensure this file is located in the same directory where you execute the CLI
command.

Generates starter configuration templates for publishing to EarthCODE openscience
catalog.

Publishes metadata of experiment, workflow and dataset to the EarthCODE open-science
catalog

DATASET_CONFIG - Path to the dataset configuration YAML file
(e.g., dataset-config.yaml)

WORKFLOW_CONFIG - Path to the workflow configuration YAML file
(e.g., workflow-config.yaml)

--environment, -e - Target catalog environment:
production (default) | staging | testing
For this tutorial in the EDC environment we’ll directly call the deepcode publish function
For this tutorial we will directly use the deep-code package functions, and not the CLI commands. Deep-code is under active development and will soon be available as a downloadable conda package

from deep_code.tools.publish import Publisher
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

# Get the absolute path of the notebook
# Jupyter notebooks don’t have __file__, so usually you set it manually
notebook_path = os.path.abspath("publish-pangeo.ipynb")
notebook_dir = os.path.dirname(notebook_path)

# Change working directory
os.chdir(notebook_dir)

# Confirm
print("Current Working Directory:", os.getcwd())
To use deep-code to publish our data we will need to define a couple of environment variables and files.
First we need to give it access to our Github

children.label: Creating a .gitaccess File for GitHub Authentication

children.value: To enable deep-code to publish your work you must create a
file with a GitHub personal access token (PAT) that grants repository access.
1. Generate a GitHub Personal Access Token (PAT)

children.label: 1. Generate a GitHub Personal Access Token (PAT)

children.value: GitHub → Settings → Developer settings → Personal access tokens
Choose the following scopes to ensure full access:
(Full control of repositories — includes fork, pull, push, and read)
Create a plain text file named
in your project directory or home folder:

github-username: your-git-user
github-token: personal access token
with your actual GitHub username and token.
S3 Configuration for Public Data Access

children.label: S3 Configuration for Public Data Access

children.value: , your data must be publicly accessible. In this example, we use a public S3 bucket hosted at:
If your dataset is hosted in a public cloud location, simply configure the following environment variables to allow
to access your data and automatically generate the appropriate EarthCODE options in a .env file. This will be loaded by load_dotenv() in the cell below

load_dotenv()  # take environment variables
import os
os.environ.get("S3_USER_STORAGE_BUCKET")
Uploading Data to a Public S3 Bucket with
- For Reference Only, We Recommend Uploading your Data to the ESA PRR!

children.label: Uploading Data to a Public S3 Bucket with xcube - For Reference Only, We Recommend Uploading your Data to the ESA PRR!

children.value: The cell bellow provides a quick walkthrough on how to create a publicly accessible S3 bucket and upload data to it using

children.label: Step 1: Create a Public S3 Bucket

Acknowledge the warning about making the bucket public.
To make objects in the bucket publicly accessible, apply the following
to access and write to your S3 bucket in the cell below, define the following environment variables (to be loaded by loadenv()):
Replace the placeholders with your actual AWS credentials. These are required for programmatic access and uploading data securely.
Step 3: Upload a Zarr Dataset Using xcube

children.label: Step 3: Upload a Zarr Dataset Using xcube

children.value: is a versatile Python library designed for working with spatiotemporal Earth observation data. It provides a unified interface to access, transform, analyze, and publish multidimensional datasets in cloud-optimized formats like Zarr. One of its key strengths is the ability to interact with a wide variety of storage backends — including local filesystems, object stores like Amazon S3, and remote services — using a consistent data store abstraction.
In this context and the cell below,

is used to publish a local Zarr dataset to an S3 bucket, making it publicly accessible for further use in cloud-native geospatial workflows. This is particularly useful for EarthCODE applications or for distributing large EO datasets in an open and scalable manner.
The code example below demonstrates how to:
Load a local Zarr dataset using
Configure an authenticated S3 data store through
Write the dataset into the specified bucket under a desired object key
, the upload process abstracts away the S3 APIs.

Keeping Your Data Open via ESA Projects Results Repository

children.label: Keeping Your Data Open via ESA Projects Results Repository

children.value: For the above dataset the storage footprint is small and it will not be operationally used other than for this tutorials - but when hosting bigger datasets one needs to consider that there are costs involved.

offers a powerful, low-friction solution for sharing and preserving the outputs of your ESA-funded Earth observation projects. Instead of worrying about cloud infrastructure, data storage, or long-term access, you can rely on a professionally maintained, FAIR-aligned repository that ensures your results are accessible, reusable, and citable.
: You don’t need to host or maintain storage — we take care of it.
: Results are stored and served from ESA-managed infrastructure, ensuring persistence and reliability.
: Your datasets are made publicly accessible in cloud-native formats (e.g., Zarr, STAC), supporting downstream use in notebooks, APIs, and platforms like
: All submissions are curated to meet Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable standards.
: We help you publish your results with globally recognized identifiers to support citation and traceability.
You can also choose to use the
— maintained by ESA — to store your project outcomes. The EarthCODE team will
If you would like to store your results and publish them through EarthCODE, simply get in touch with us at:
We’re here to help make your data discoverable, reusable, and impactful.
In the near future, tools such as
will include built-in support for uploading and registering your results as part of the publishing workflow — making it even easier to share your scientific contributions with the community.
Great — we’ve uploaded the data and made it publicly accessible. Now, to use
, the final step is to define a few simple metadata entries in a YAML file — one for your
to automatically generate STAC Items that follow the
, and submit a pull request to register them in the
When defining your dataset metadata, you’ll provide key fields that describe
it aligns with the Open Science Catalog.
Here’s a breakdown of the required fields:

dataset_id: The name of the dataset object within your S3 bucket
collection_id: A unique identifier for the dataset collection
osc_themes: [wildfires] Open Science theme (choose from https://opensciencedata.esa.int/themes/catalog)
documentation_link: Link to relevant documentation, publication, or handbook
access_link: Public S3 URL to the dataset
dataset_status: Status of the dataset: 'ongoing', 'completed', or 'planned'
osc_region: Geographical coverage, e.g. 'global'
cf_parameter: The main geophysical variable, ideally matching a CF standard name or OSC variable
must match one of the themes listed at:
should reference a well-established variable name, ideally from the Open Science Catalog or CF conventions.
You can explore examples by searching the EarthCODE metadata repository:

workflow_id: A unique identifier for your workflow
properties:
    title: Human-readable title of the workflow
    description: A concise summary of what the workflow does
    keywords: Relevant scientific or technical keywords
    themes: Thematic area(s) of focus (e.g. land, ocean, atmosphere) - see from above example
    license: License type (e.g. MIT, Apache-2.0, CC-BY-4.0, proprietary)
    jupyter_kernel_info:
        name: Name of the execution environment or notebook kernel
        python_version: Python version used
        env_file: Link to the environment file (YAML) used to create the notebook environment
jupyter_notebook_url: Link to the source notebook (e.g. on GitHub)
contact:
    name: Contact person's full name
    organization: Affiliated institution or company
    links:
        rel: "about"
        type: "text/html"
        href: Link to homepage or personal/institutional profile

dataset_config="""
dataset_id: dnbr_dataset.zarr
collection_id: pangeo-test
osc_themes:
- 'land'
documentation_link: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1470160X22004708#f0035
access_link: s3://pangeo-test-fires
dataset_status: completed
osc_region: global
cf_parameter:
  - name: burned-area
"""

with open("dataset_config.yaml", 'w') as f:
    f.write(dataset_config)

workflow_config="""
workflow_id: "dnbr_workflow_example"
properties:
  title: "DNBR Workflow Example"
  description: "Demonstrate how to fetch satellite Sentinel-2 data to generate burn severity maps for the assessment of the areas affected by wildfires."
  keywords:
    - Earth Science
  themes:
      - land
  license: proprietary
  jupyter_kernel_info:
    name: Pange-Test-Notebook
    python_version: 3.11
    env_file: "https://github.com/pangeo-data/pangeo-docker-images/blob/master/pangeo-notebook/environment.yml"
jupyter_notebook_url: "https://github.com/pangeo-data/pangeo-openeo-BiDS-2023/blob/main/tutorial/examples/dask/wildfires_daskgateway.ipynb"
contact:
  - name: Dean Summers
    organization: Lampata
    links:
      - rel: "about"
        type: "text/html"
        href: "https://www.lampata.eu/"
"""

with open("workflow_config.yaml", 'w') as f:
    f.write(workflow_config)
can submit metadata to the Open Science Catalog via Git, you may need to configure your Git identity in the environment where you’re running it:

git config --global user.email "your-email@example.com"
git config --global user.name "Your Name"

For this tutorial in the EDC environment we’ll directly call the deepcode publish function via the library code to make sure this code is easily reproducible (as deep-code is currently evolving and changing rapidly with more users publishing to EarthCODE!)

publisher = Publisher(
    dataset_config_path="dataset_config.yaml",
    workflow_config_path="workflow_config.yaml",
    environment="staging",
)
publisher.publish_all()

children.value: completes the submission, it automatically opens a pull request in the EarthCODE Open Science Catalog staging repository. You can:
Check the actual pull request generated by
This allows you to inspect exactly what metadata files were created — saving you the time and effort of writing and formatting them manually.
Preview and edit your submission in the EarthCODE Staging Dashboard
This UI provides an intuitive way to browse, validate, and refine your submission before it’s merged into the main Open Science Catalog.
Together, these tools streamline the publishing workflow and help ensure your data and workflows are cleanly documented and catalogued.
